div.p: Greetings. Today I finally received your letter written on August 28.

The people of Lucerne are requesting a meeting to be convened, but they do not indicate the reasons; it is scheduled for the 27th of this month. Many suspect that they will act on the instigation of the Pope and the Emperor; but we shall hear. We will overcome all evil with true faith, prayers, and steadfastness. I do not hear a word about the council. The war in Italy is escalating; the Pope is furiously angry with the French; for the affairs of the French are going well. The Turkish fleet is said to have sailed to Africa; it is said that 60,000 Turkish horses have come to Pannonia. Certainly, some garrisons have been sent to Austria. Thus, everything is arranged in such a way that I gather many evils are threatening our necks. The Lord will not abandon those who fight with true faith. In this, farewell forever; I could not write more, overwhelmed by the crowd of people coming and going. The Emperor is entirely focused on eradicating the doctrine of the Gospel; he is already fighting with exile, soon he will fight with the sword, etc. Farewell again. Zurich, September 13, 1551.
To the most excellent man, Mr. Oswald Myconius, faithful leader of the Basel church, venerable lord and dearest brother. Basel.
